content:
Lately, I’ve been spending some time exploring Hugo, an open-source static site generator. I didn’t get interested in it for no reason. I’ve loved writing since junior high school, and over the years I’ve jumped between different writing platforms, starting from Blogger, then WordPress, and later Medium. Blogger feels outdated now, WordPress requires too much setup, and Medium just doesn’t feel very user-friendly to me.
Hugo feels like the right answer to my need for a simple place to write casual thoughts straight from my head. I was already familiar with Markdown from writing programming documentation in the past, so there was basically no learning curve. On top of that, Hugo has a lot of clean, minimalist themes, which I really like.
The installation experience was also surprisingly smooth on Arch Linux. Just one command:
sudo pacman -S hugo and I immediately got the extended version. After a full day of tinkering, I finally found a setup that feels perfect for me. I can write freely without worrying about hosting or domains by using GitHub Pages and GitHub Actions. The documentation for setting everything up is already well written on the official Hugo website, which makes the whole process even easier.
Another reason behind this website is someone I know named Ahmad Saugi. Recently, he’s been practicing what I’d call atomic habits. He writes short, lightweight notes about what he learns each day. Seeing that really inspired me and pushed me to finally build this site. He also uses Hugo and even created his own theme, which is honestly pretty impressive. You can check out his website at https://til.saugi.me.
I hope I can stay consistent writing here. For me, this is the easiest and simplest way to write. No overthinking, no unnecessary setup. Just getting what’s in my head out and turning it into words.
summary: A short story about how I discovered Hugo, why it fits my writing style, and how it helps me write freely without worrying about platforms, hosting, or complexity.
title: Finding My Writing Home with Hugo

Designing for attention starts with defending your own. This is a short field guide to protect focus without turning into a monk.
The Rule of One Window #Keep one intentional window open: the one where the work happens. Every extra tab is a tiny promise you will break later.
A Tiny Checklist # What must exist when I stop today? What is the smallest version that proves the idea? What can I delete without guilt? A Quote That Helps # If you don‚Äôt guard your time, the internet will schedule it for you.
A Small Table # Signal Noise Replace With endless tabs false options a short list alerts fragmented time a single inbox vague goals drift a clear deliverable A Compact Timeline # Morning: produce the core artifact Midday: tighten and ship the smallest slice Evening: record what to fix next A Pull Quote # Make the work visible, make the scope small, make the finish real. A Callout # No tool will rescue a vague goal. Tools amplify clarity or confusion. An Image #Add a header image by placing an asset next to this file or in assets/ and referencing it in front matter.
A Little Math #When you care about sharpness, you pick fewer things and do them better.
37503\text{focus} = \frac{\text{intention}}{\text{distraction} + 1}37503
The Close #The hardest part of creating is making a clear line. I stop here so tomorrow has a place to begin.
summary: A field guide to protecting deep work in a world of pings.
title: Signal Over Noise
